newsitem.title: USA: ALPINE SKIING-KIWI AUSTRIAN CLAUDIA RIEGLER WINS SLALOM.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-KIWI AUSTRIAN CLAUDIA RIEGLER WINS SLALOM.

text.p: Claudia Riegler, the latest Austrian skiier to strike it rich under a different country's banner, took another step towards stardom Saturday with a victory in the season's first World Cup slalom.

Riegler, who skis for New Zealand, held off world champion Pernilla Wiberg of Sweden to claim her second career victory with a time of 1:36.50. A strong second run by Wiberg made it close at the finish at 1:36.57.

Austrian veteran Ingrid Salvenmoser took third in 1:37.49, her best result since 1991. Patricia Chauvet of France was fourth and Sabine Egger of Austria fifth, an eyeblink ahead of Deborah Compagnoni of Italy.
Much like countryman Marc Girardelli 15 years earlier, Riegler left the Austrian team three years ago because of frustration over being trapped among the country's masses of fine young racers.

With a New Zealand mother, Riegler claimed dual citizenship and quickly blossomed. Now the 20-year-old looks to have a chance to follow Girardelli, who won five overall World Cup titles and a bushel of medals, as a champion.
She earned her first World Cup victory, also a slalom, midway through last season, then finished fourth -- "the worst place," she called it -- at the world championships.
"It's great to be back on top of the podium. I take a lot of risks, but I know I can win when I cam make it," Riegler said.

Her second run typified that attacking style and, for a scary few seconds, nearly cost the race. Flailing wildly through the first few gates, she suddenly settled into solid form and finished strongly.
"I really blew the start and that made me upset. So I attacked some more after that."

Riegler, who still holds to her Austrian heritage and continues her schooling in her native Salzburg, had a tough challenge her first World Cup season, when, without sponsors or a national team, her parents absorbed more than $50,000 in annual expenses for a coach and travel.
Now she is established among the stars of the sport with a rich future.
Wiberg, in her eighth season with five Olympic and World Championship medals, has quite a different agenda.
"After my bad result in giant slalom two days ago, I just wanted to come through. I skied conservatively, under control both runs."

The Swedish strategy was a good one on a course still soft and treacherous after the rain the previous day that postponed a men's giant slalom. The course held up well under the circumstances and the way seems clear for Sunday's men's slalom and Monday's makeup men's giant slalom.
Salvenmoser, in her 14th season at age 29, took her success, achieved largely with the fastest second run, as a harbinger of better things to come.
"After so long from the podium, it's a great feeling. I now know what I need to have a victory. This gives me great confidence."
